Situation1: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Story: I sat on the edge of the bed, my phone buzzing with reminders from my manager—today was the last day of the quarter, and I was still three sales short of my target. The pressure was suffocating; missing the quota meant not just losing my bonus, but letting my whole team down. But next to me, my girlfriend lay curled up, her eyes red and swollen from crying. She’d just lost her brother, and every few minutes, a fresh wave of grief would hit her. She needed me—needed my arms around her, my words, my presence. I could feel her expectation, unspoken but heavy: to be here, to listen, to hold her together when she was falling apart. But my phone kept lighting up, each message a reminder of the other world I belonged to, where empathy didn’t count for much, only numbers did. My heart twisted as I stared at the screen, torn between the desperate need to be the boyfriend she deserved and the relentless demand to be the telemarketer my job required.
